title: 113_hr3357
content: The "Early Childhood Education Professional Improvement Act of 2013" aims to enhance the qualifications, compensation, and professional development of early childhood educators in various programs. This includes Head Start Programs, state-funded prekindergarten programs, licensed child care for prekindergarten children, and special education preschools. The Act also authorizes a program to provide assistance to states for this purpose. The Secretary of Education, with input from the Secretary of Health and Human Services, can grant funds to States for implementing activities outlined in section 6. Applications for the grants are authorized. Each State seeking a grant under this Act must submit an application to the Secretary of Education with details of their early childhood professional development system developed in collaboration with various stakeholders. The State applying for a grant must designate an agency to administer the program and describe how their system provides oversight, professional standards, career advancement, coordination with higher education institutions, and articulation agreements. The State applying for a grant must designate an agency to administer the program and describe oversight, professional standards, career advancement, coordination with higher education institutions, and articulation agreements. Additionally, the grant should focus on providing more accessible higher education for working learners, support for adult learners from low-income or minority communities, use of workforce data to assess workforce needs, and financing over time. State funds must be used according to the guidelines set forth in the grant application, focusing on accessible higher education, support for adult learners from low-income or minority communities, workforce data assessment, and financing over time. A State receiving a grant under this Act must use the funds for scholarships covering tuition, fees, materials, transportation, and release time for preschool teachers pursuing a bachelor's degree in early childhood education. The funds can also support preschool teachers with a bachelor's degree in a different field to obtain credentials in early childhood education and increase compensation for teachers working towards an early childhood education degree. The grant aims to support preschool teachers pursuing a degree in early childhood education by providing scholarships for tuition, fees, materials, transportation, and release time. It also focuses on providing professional development opportunities that cover all areas of child development, teacher-child interaction, family engagement, and cultural competence for working with diverse children and families. The Act emphasizes that grant funds should supplement, not replace, existing federal, state, and local funds for early childhood educator preparation. States receiving funds must maintain or increase their financial support for activities covered by the Act. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2014 through 2019.
